metadata.title: What is Sentiment Analysis and how is it used? | by Ryan Basques | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: What is Sentiment Analysis and how is it used?
metadata.description: How does a machine know when you're upset? We'll learn what sentiment analysis is, where it came from, and how it's solving our difficult problems.

all_paragraphs: When was the last time you flew on a plane? Can you remember?
Maybe you sat next to the one crying baby… or maybe you were given a free upgrade and enjoyed more leg room.
Maybe the flight attendant spilled coffee on you… or maybe they were pleasant and made you feel at ease.
Or maybe you don’t even remember your last flight because nothing memorable happened—probably a good thing!
Regardless of your experience, you might receive a survey sent out by your airline. They want to know how the flight was through your perspective.
Some survey questions may ask you to rate a service from 1–10, like how helpful the flight attendants were, or how clean the bathrooms were.
They may also ask open-ended questions—“Tell us about your experience and anything we can do to improve.”
Let’s look at United Airlines as an example. According to their most recent fact sheet, United had 162 million passengers last year.
If we can assume that their marketing department randomly sends out a survey to every 30th person, and gets a response rate of 5%, then:
That’s a lot of data! That’s 270,000 cells in a spreadsheet with free-text answers to what United can do to improve their service.
The opinions contained in this data are incredibly valuable to management for figuring out how to make their passengers happier.
Unfortunately, for many companies the next step is to have a room full of interns split and scour the spreadsheet. Or worse, the spreadsheet is pushed into a dark corner never to be seen again.
However, to save intern sanity and the insights waiting to be revealed, we can leverage the fascinating method of sentiment analysis.

Sentiment simply describes an opinion about something — whether an event you read about in the news, the book you bought from Amazon, or your feelings about your dog after they made a mess on the carpet.
We could probably call the practice opinion analysis, but this doesn’t sound as catchy does it?
Opinions can be fleeting and ever-changing. Your pet is the beast who ruined a carpet one minute, and is a lovable fuzz-ball of energy the next.
In our airline example, there are likely hundreds of opinions scattered among the passengers on any given flight.

In an attempt to wrangle the scattershot opinions of the masses, natural language practitioners have refined Sentiment Analysis to derive meaning from the unstructured and incredibly varied nature of opinion data.
Sentiment analysis can label our data in various ways to make it easier to gain insight from our otherwise messy unstructured data.
The first and most often used metric is polarity.

Polarity simply refers to whether language is positive, negative or neutral. Much of sentiment analysis is concerned with boiling text down into a number—say, between -10 and +10, indicating the polarity of a statement.
While “these peanuts are salty” may register as 0 (neutral polarity), we may expect “these wonderful peanuts saved my marriage” may register as +10 (positive polarity).
Meanwhile, “these rancid peanuts are gross” elicits a -8 (negative polarity).
Sentiment analysis can also label text as subjective or objective.
Subjective text implies opinionated text—not necessarily provable or fact-based. Opinions about how good or bad carrot cake is falls into this category.
Objectivity on the other hand covers fact-based language not influenced by personal opinion—like “carrot cake has carrots”.
Filtering for subjectivity is especially useful when parsing customer feedback or reviews. We don’t care that the airplane took off, we want to know how the take-off was.
Finally, there is feature-based sentiment analysis. Consider the below product review:
Notice how there is some conflicting sentiment in this text. If we tried to summarize the polarity as a whole, we might end up with something fairly neutral.
However, when we break the text into its features, we can get a much clearer and more usable idea of what this customer likes and dislikes.
Feature-based (or aspect-based) sentiment analysis is concerned with finding who the opinion-holder is, what the object is that is being evaluated, and what the actual opinion is.

In the above example, this method may be able to pick out that this customer loves the Nike brand, and thinks these shoes are cute and comfy. However, the system also sees that horrible blisters and waste of money are the negative factors associated with the shoes.

By breaking these features out, we may be much more likely to predict a 1-star review. We may even be able to recommend other Nike shoes that are cute and comfy, where “no blisters” is a feature we’ve extracted from reviews.
Given the scattered nature of opinion, and the general messiness of written language, we should pay our respects to the brave souls who first began trying to make sense of the chaos.
A study of the historical use of sentiment analysis shows that 99% of all papers on sentiment analysis take place after 2004. This is in large part due to increased computing power.
The above graph from Google Trends shows search volume since 2004. Red is customer feedback, and blue is sentiment analysis.
While customer feedback has always enjoyed prominence as an important topic, sentiment analysis has quickly caught up and even surpassed it.
Some interesting historical findings from this study shed light on some of the first attempts to use sentiment analysis:

In broad strokes, modern sentiment analysis took hold in the 2000’s. One of the first general-use tools applied cross-domain to many issues was called the “General Inquirer”. The tool was first developed with US grants in the 1990’s and became widely available for academic research around 2002.
The General Inquirer was a set of hand-coded techniques, including mapping words to a variety of categories. The biggest category is Negative (with words like awful, terrible, horrendous, etc.).

Stepping further into the 2010’s, the above cited study shows a word cloud formed from sentiment analysis papers. The bottom half represents keywords pre-2013, and the top half represents keywords since:
There is a distinct shift from “web” to “social”, and a shift to deep learning techniques like neural networks. These state-of-the-art models take us right up to the present day.
Some of the earlier attempts, including the General Inquirer, used “knowledge-based” techniques like creating a custom dictionary of hard-coded words with an “unambiguous affect”.

In other words, these techniques focused on words that rarely have a double-meaning. These words almost always indicate good or bad, like “happy”, “sad”, “afraid”, “bored”. You may also see these referred to as lexicon-based approaches.
One downside of knowledge-based techniques is that, depending on the context of your dataset, a general knowledge-based dictionary may miss out on important words.
For example, an article about cancer may talk about “unstoppable growth”. In this context, this is bad.
But in the context of an article about startup businesses, “unstoppable growth” is considered good.
To get highly accurate results for each type of data you’re looking at with the knowledge-based approach, you may need to tailor your hard-coded dictionaries. This can be time intensive.
There are some methods of knowledge-based techniques that try finding context-specific keywords automatically. One example relies on conjunctions like “and” or “but”.
Let’s say we see a sentence about “patient deterioration and unstoppable growth”. Because deterioration is found in the negative dictionary, we can infer that unstoppable growth is also negative.
This proximity of words (which also implies how they are related) is also called co-occurrence.

Knowledge-based techniques contrast with later more sophisticated “statistical” techniques and machine learning approaches. These methods rely more heavily on inference gained through large amounts of text.

If co-occurrences can be wrangled from text manually, or maybe inferred with automatic rules-based approach, then a statistical approach is leveraged in a more automated way that can scale to billions of data points.
With this statistical approach we use a massive amount of data to make inferences about co-occurrence relatively quickly.
If a word is often found among polar-positive words, we assign a positive polarity to that word, too. Same for negative words.

We keep iterating and training over a large corpus of text—say, all articles in Wikipedia. Ultimately, the outcome is a weighting for most words in the English language that we can then use for predicting sentiment of new text.

Note that this works for context-specific natural language, too. In our earlier medical text example, we would train our model on only a corpus of medical literature to capture polarity of subject-specific keywords.
Much of the statistical approach still relies on the meanings of individual words—keeping a sort of scoreboard for the sentiment of a given text.

But we must also consider the interactions between words. Semantic analysis models are more accurate when considering the meaning of many words in a longer phrase or sentence. Of course, this means we must train more complicated models that use more computational resources and take longer to run.
“A friend told me I would love this sandwich.
Even though I normally love good peanut butter, the type used here is not creamy enough.
The jelly is good but there’s just not enough of it.”

This PB&J review has lots of mixed signals. We’d assign a relatively positive polarity to it if we focused on only the words themselves without the phrases they’re used in. There’s a lot of “love” and “good”, for example.

While a deeper dive of neural networks is outside the scope of this discussion, it is important to know that these models can hold and weigh millions of features about the text in order to ultimately provide a prediction on polarity.
For example, a trained neural network may analyze the text sentence-by-sentence and word-by-word.

If “Even though” is used earlier in the sentence, the model may discount positive sentiment for the rest of the sentence. Similarly, “good but” will likely be discounted, and “love this sandwich” may be correctly attributed to the customer’s friend instead of the customer themself.
Nicely done! If you’ve made it this far, you’ve gained a good understanding of what sentiment analysis is and how it works behind the scenes to extract extremely valuable insights.

Needless to say, NLP is rapidly growing and changing—sentiment analysis along with it. By the time I publish this there will probably be another breakthrough in methodology that allows even greater accuracy.

In the meantime, if you are interested in learning more about sentiment analysis, one of the best things you can do is to start exploring and practicing hands-on. Come up with a problem you think could be solved with one of the methods we’ve described above, and get coding!
